The morphologic features of this tumor fall into the category of atypical Spitz tumor of uncertain biologic potential. Due to the inherent limitations in the ability of morphologic assessment to accurately predict clinical behavior in Spitzoid lesions, the tumor was submitted for the melanoma fluorescence in situ hybridization test to further assess the potential for aggressive behavior.  The melanoma fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) test was positive for MYB loss (see attached report ***). There is preliminary data to suggest that atypical Spitz tumors with isolated MYB (6q23) loss show less evidence of aggressive behavior (e.g. advanced locoregional spread, distant metastases, or death) than atypical Spitz tumors with gains in RREB1 or CCND1 or 9p21 deletion (see references below). These tumors have been provisionally termed atypical Spitz tumor with 6q23 deletion, and appear to represent a subset of Spitzoid neoplasms that often result in a positive sentinel lymph node but only occasionally progress beyond this; although the data are limited and further follow-up studies are needed. 1.
